sources.name: Human Rights Protection Scores – by Christopher Farris and Keith Schnakenberg
sources.description:
Description:
Data published by These data were published in the following two papers:
  • Christopher J. Fariss. 2014. Respect for Human Rights has Improved Over Time: Modeling the Changing Standard of Accountability. American Political Science Review 108(2):297-318 (May 2014).
    • - Supplementary Materials
  • Keith Schnakenberg and Christopher J. Fariss. 2014. Dynamic Patterns of Human Rights Practices. Political Science Research and Methods 2(1):1-31 (April 2014).

Linkhumanrightsscores.org
Retrieved6 June 2016. Christopher Farris kindly provided this dataset and shared it with Max Roser via email.

Additional information

The original dataset includes the country ids 666.001, 666.002, and 666.003. These correspond to different human rights reports which were produced for distinct areas in Israel (Israel, pre-1967 borders Israel, occupied territories Palestinian Authority). Because of technical limitations they cannot be shown in these visualisations and shown is only the 'Israel' series.

variables.name: xHuman Rights Protection Scores – by Christopher Farris and Keith Schnakenberg
variables.description: The estimates represent the relative position of one country-year unit to all others: This means, a zero score represents the average level of observed physical integrity abuses for the entire period (1949-2014). The human rights scores represent standard
variables.coverage: Globally, by country and world average
